   Comments:
   pO2: No Calls Made - Not Arterial Blood
   Type:[**Last Name (un) **]
   Na:131

   Hgb:11.4
   CalcHCT:34
   Dark as well as some bright blood were seen in the stomach. A large
   clot that was found adhereing to the fundus during earlier
   endoscopy was now seen to extend from the fundus upto beyond the
   pylorus. After extensive flushing, the clot was dislodged and passed
   below into the antrum and pylorus. Subsequently a subcutaneous
   appearing blood vessel with mild oozing was noted in the fundus, likely
   a Dieulafuoy lesion.[10][1] The vessel was injected with a total of 8ml
   of 1:10,000 epinephrine. Attempts to clip the vessel failed three times
   due to mucosal sloughing. Subsequently the vessel was cauterized with a
   gold probe and hemostasis was achieved.
   Assessment and Plan
   49 y/o F with DM2, HTN,  CAD s/p CABG, admitted/in hospital for MSSA
   bacteremia, charcot foot infected with MSSA, hypotension from sepsis
   with [**Hospital **] transferred from medical [**Hospital1 **] with upper GI bleed likely from
   ASA/Plavix in setting of critical illness and prior hx of ulcers.
   Upper GI Bleed: active bleeding that did not clear with NG lavage. GI
   urgently consulted. Emergently establish access with Central Line ([**Location (un) **])
   and peripheral 20 G in addition to single lumen power-PICC
   -          Maintain [**Location (un) **] and power-PICC (both equivalent to > 18G)
   -          NPO
   -          Maintain active T&S
   -          IV protonix bolus, then drip
   -          Transfuse 3 units pRBCs, and 1 unit of platelets stat, then
   check post
transfusion HCT
   -          Transfuse to HCT > 25 given coronary history and baseline
   HCT of 30
   -          Give DDAVP for uremic platelets in the setting of renal
   failure
   -          Q4H HCT
   -          Appreciate GI recommendation
   -          Plan for scope in unit
   Leukocytosis: no clear source other than foot,  known bacteremia which
   has cleared per blood cultures or diarrhea that is c. diff neg. Could
   be stress response to GI bleed
   -          Trend, add on diff
   -          Repeat blood cultures
   -          Follow-up CXR
   -          Follow-up repeat C. diff pending
   -          Repeat Ucx, given foley catheter in place
   -          Monitor clinical exam
   MSSA Bacteremia: repeat blood cultures negative. Temp [**3-7**] to 99.5 on
   standing tylenol.
   -          Continue nafcillin (does not need renal dosing)
   -          Repeat blood cultures
   -          Appreciate ID recommendations
   Left Charcot Foot and Cellulitis:
   -          Continue nafcillin
   -          Follow-up on final tissue cultures
   -          Monitor for improvement
   -          Appreciate podiatric surgery recommendations
   [**Last Name (un) **] d/t ATN: patient without known CKD at baseline. ATN attributed to
   hypotension in setting of MSSA bacteremia. Peak Cr 4.3.
   -          Renally dose all meds
   -          Hold sevelamer while NPO
   -          Monitor UOP, trend Cr
   -          Keep MAPs > 60 to maintain renal perfusion
   -          Appreciate renal consult recommendations
   Hyponatremia: 130,  in setting volume depletion. Has been an issue
   throughout hospitalization and improves with volume and hydration
   -          Hydrate as above
   -          Trend Na with [**Hospital1 **] lytes
   Diarrhea: currently in setting of melena, but prior likely antibiotic
   associated with multiple negative c. diff
   -          When able to tolerate PO initiate yogurt in diet /
   probiotics
   -          Consider loperamide once GI bleed resolves and if there is
   no evidence for infection
   Cervical Disc Disease: C6-C7 disc herniation
   -          Appreciate spine consultation recommendations
   -          Will hold on CT C spine w/o contrast until patient stable
   from a Upper GI bleed perspective
   DM c/b retinopathy, neuropathy:
   -          Lantus to 20 units (half dose) QHS given NPO status
   -          Got 40 units of glargine last night, q2H fingersticks and
   may need D5 drip given NPO
   -          Continue HISS but only treat BG > 200 given currently NPO
   -          Renally dose gabapentin and hold until while patient NPO
   Pain: concern that tylenol could be masking fevers
   -          Stop tylenol for 48 hours to trend temperature curve
   -          Continue dilaudid IV for pain
   HTN:
   -          Continue to hold norvasc, lasix, lopressor, valsartan
   -          Monitor BPs
   CAD s/p CABG [**2197**]:  last intervention > 1 year ago, given acute upper
   GI bleed need to stop ASA and Plavix.
   -          Restart imdur when able
   -          Check EKG
   Diastolic CHF:
   -          Consider using lasix with blood transfusions to prevent
   fluid overload.
   HL: hold atorvastatin and fish oil while NPO
   Anemia, baseline 31: hold iron, MVI
   Vitamin D Deficiency: hold vitamin D
   ICU Care
   Nutrition:
   Glycemic Control:
   Lines:
   PICC Line - [**2207-3-8**] 07:18 AM
   20 Gauge - [**2207-3-8**] 09:00 AM
   [**First Name4 (NamePattern1) **] [**Last Name (NamePattern1) **] - [**2207-3-8**] 09:26 AM
   Prophylaxis:
   DVT:
   Stress ulcer:
   VAP:
   Comments:
   Communication:  Comments:
   Code status: Full code
   Disposition:
   _______________________
   [11][1] Dieulafoy's lesion is a medical condition characterized by a
   large tortuous arteriole in the stomach wall that erodes and bleeds. It
   can cause gastric hemorrhage but is relatively uncommon. It is thought
   to cause less than 5% of all gastrointestinal bleeds in adults. It was
   named after [**Name2 (NI) 4162**] surgeon [**First Name4 (NamePattern1) 98**] [**Name (NI) 11867**] Dieulafoy, who described this
   condition in his paper "Exulceratio simplex: Le
ons [**12-28**]" in 1898. It is
   also called "caliber-persistent artery" or "aneurysm" of gastric
   vessels. However, unlike most other aneurysms these are thought to be
   developmental malformations rather than degenerative changes.

   large tortuous arteriole in the stomach wall that erodes and bleeds. It
   can cause gastric hemorrhage but is relatively uncommon. It is thought
   to cause less than 5% of all gastrointestinal bleeds in adults. It was
   named after [**Name2 (NI) 4162**] surgeon [**First Name4 (NamePattern1) 98**] [**Name (NI) 11867**] Dieulafoy, who described this
   condition in his paper "Exulceratio simplex: Le
ons [**12-28**]" in 1898. It is
   also called "caliber-persistent artery" or "aneurysm" of gastric
   vessels. However, unlike most other aneurysms these are thought to be
   developmental malformations rather than degenerative changes.

Based on the physician's daily progress note, I summarize the patient's health progress in the ICU as follows:

The patient, a 49-year-old female with a history of diabetes, hypertension, coronary artery disease, and chronic kidney disease, was admitted to the hospital for MSSA bacteremia, Charcot foot infected with MSSA, and hypotension from sepsis. She was transferred from another hospital with an upper gastrointestinal bleed likely due to ASA/Plavix in the setting of critical illness and prior history of ulcers.

The patient's current condition is:

* Hemodynamically unstable with a blood pressure of 190/93 mmHg and a heart rate of 85 bpm
* Respiratory support with CPAP/PSV and an FiO2 of 40%
* Intubated and mechanically ventilated
* Large clot in the stomach, which was dislodged and passed below into the antrum and pylorus
* Dieulafoy's lesion was identified and cauterized with a gold probe to achieve hemostasis
* Renal failure with a peak creatinine of 4.3 mg/dL
* Hyponatremia with a sodium level of 130 mmol/L
* Diarrhea and abdominal pain
* Cervical disc disease with a herniation at C6-C7
* Diabetes with a history of retinopathy and neuropathy
* Pain managed with dilaudid IV
* HTN managed with holding of antihypertensive medications

Potential medical complications that can arise include:

1. Bleeding: The patient has an ongoing upper gastrointestinal bleed, and there is a risk of further bleeding due to the presence of a large clot in the stomach.
2. Infection: The patient has MSSA bacteremia and Charcot foot infected with MSSA, which increases the risk of further infection.
3. Renal failure: The patient's creatinine level is elevated, and there is a risk of further deterioration in renal function.
4. Hyponatremia: The patient's sodium level is low, and there is a risk of further dehydration and electrolyte imbalance.
5. Cervical disc disease: The patient has a herniation at C6-C7, which can cause further spinal cord compression and neurological deficits.
6. Diabetes: The patient has a history of retinopathy and neuropathy, which can worsen with further hyperglycemia.
7. HTN: The patient's blood pressure is elevated, and there is a risk of further cardiovascular complications.

The patient's care plan includes:

1. Maintenance of hemodynamic stability with fluid management and vasopressor support
2. Management of respiratory support with CPAP/PSV and FiO2
3. Monitoring of renal function and electrolyte levels
4. Management of pain with dilaudid IV
5. Monitoring of Cervical disc disease and potential spinal cord compression
6. Management of diabetes with insulin and blood glucose monitoring
7. Monitoring of HTN and cardiovascular risk factors

The patient's condition requires close monitoring and management to prevent further complications and ensure optimal care.

   [11][1] Dieulafoy's lesion is a medical condition characterized by a
   large tortuous arteriole in the stomach wall that erodes and bleeds. It
   can cause gastric hemorrhage but is relatively uncommon. It is thought
   to cause less than 5% of all gastrointestinal bleeds in adults. It was
   named after [**Name2 (NI) 4162**] surgeon [**First Name4 (NamePattern1) 98**] [**Name (NI) 11867**] Dieulafoy, who described this
   condition in his paper "Exulceratio simplex: Le
ons [**12-28**]" in 1898. It is
   also called "caliber-persistent artery" or "aneurysm" of gastric
   vessels. However, unlike most other aneurysms these are thought to be
   developmental malformations rather than degenerative changes.

Based on the provided physician's daily progress note, the patient is a 24-year-old female who was admitted to the ICU with a chief complaint of upper gastrointestinal bleeding. The patient's hemoglobin level was 17% at admission, and she received 4 units of packed red blood cells (PRBCs) during the 24-hour period. The patient's hemoglobin level improved to 25% after the transfusions.

The patient's condition was unstable, with a blood pressure of 190/93 mmHg and a heart rate of 85 beats per minute. She was intubated and mechanically ventilated, and her oxygen saturation was 100% on a FiO2 of 40%. The patient's respiratory support included CPAP/PSV mode with a Vt of 680 mL and a PS of 10 cmH2O.

The patient's laboratory results showed a white blood cell count of 21.9 x 10^9/L, a platelet count of 442 x 10^9/L, and a lactate level of 0.9 mmol/L. Her electrolyte levels were within normal limits, with the exception of a potassium level of 3.4 mmol/L.

The patient's imaging studies showed a large clot in the stomach, which was dislodged and passed below into the antrum and pylorus. A subcutaneous appearing blood vessel with mild oozing was noted in the fundus, which was likely a Dieulafoy lesion. The vessel was injected with epinephrine and cauterized with a gold probe to achieve hemostasis.

The patient's code status is full code, and she is being managed in the ICU with close monitoring of her vital signs and laboratory results. She is receiving prophylactic anticoagulation therapy to prevent deep vein thrombosis and stress ulcer prophylaxis to prevent gastrointestinal bleeding.

Potential medical complications that can arise in this patient include:

1. Hemorrhagic shock: The patient's blood pressure is elevated, and she is receiving PRBCs, which can increase the risk of hemorrhagic shock.
2. Respiratory failure: The patient is intubated and mechanically ventilated, and her oxygen saturation is 100% on a FiO2 of 40%. She may require further respiratory support, such as increased FiO2 or positive end-expiratory pressure (PEEP).
3. Sepsis: The patient has a white blood cell count of 21.9 x 10^9/L, which is elevated, and her lactate level is 0.9 mmol/L, which may indicate sepsis.
4. Deep vein thrombosis: The patient is receiving prophylactic anticoagulation therapy, but she may still be at risk for deep vein thrombosis due to her immobilization and underlying medical conditions.
5. Stress ulcer: The patient is receiving stress ulcer prophylaxis, but she may still be at risk for stress ulceration due to her underlying medical conditions and the use of anticoagulation therapy.

In summary, the patient is a 24-year-old female who was admitted to the ICU with a chief complaint of upper gastrointestinal bleeding. She received 4 units of PRBCs during the 24-hour period and is being managed in the ICU with close monitoring of her vital signs and laboratory results. She is at risk for various medical complications, including hemorrhagic shock, respiratory failure, sepsis, deep vein thrombosis, and stress ulcer.

   clot that was found adhereing to the fundus during earlier
   endoscopy was now seen to extend from the fundus upto beyond the
   pylorus. After extensive flushing, the clot was dislodged and passed
   below into the antrum and pylorus. Subsequently a subcutaneous
   appearing blood vessel with mild oozing was noted in the fundus, likely
   a Dieulafuoy lesion.[1][1] The vessel was injected with a total of 8ml
   of 1:10,000 epinephrine. Attempts to clip the vessel failed three times
   due to mucosal sloughing. Subsequently the vessel was cauterized with a
   gold probe and hemostasis was achieved.

   [2][1] Dieulafoy's lesion is a medical condition characterized by a
   large tortuous arteriole in the stomach wall that erodes and bleeds. It
   can cause gastric hemorrhage but is relatively uncommon. It is thought
   to cause less than 5% of all gastrointestinal bleeds in adults. It was
   named after [**Name2 (NI) 4162**] surgeon [**First Name4 (NamePattern1) 98**] [**Name (NI) 11867**] Dieulafoy, who described this
   condition in his paper "Exulceratio simplex: Le
ons [**12-28**]" in 1898. It is
   also called "caliber-persistent artery" or "aneurysm" of gastric
   vessels. However, unlike most other aneurysms these are thought to be
   developmental malformations rather than degenerative changes.

Summary:

The patient is a critically ill individual who was admitted to the ICU with a diagnosis of gastric bleeding and a large clot in the stomach. The patient's hemoglobin level has been decreasing, and they have required multiple units of blood transfusions. The patient's blood pressure has been fluctuating, and they have developed hypertension. The patient's respiratory status is stable, and they are receiving oxygen therapy.

Potential medical complications:

1. Hemorrhagic shock: The patient's bleeding has been significant, and they may be at risk of developing hemorrhagic shock if the bleeding is not controlled.
2. Infection: The patient's blood products and IV lines may increase the risk of infection.
3. Organ failure: The patient's underlying medical condition and the use of blood products and IV lines may increase the risk of organ failure.
4. Respiratory failure: The patient's respiratory status may deteriorate if they develop pneumonia or other respiratory complications.
5. Cardiovascular complications: The patient's hypertension and tachycardia may increase the risk of cardiovascular complications such as myocardial infarction or stroke.
6. Neurological complications: The patient's hypertension and tachycardia may increase the risk of neurological complications such as seizures or cerebral edema.
7. Gastrointestinal complications: The patient's bleeding and use of blood products may increase the risk of gastrointestinal complications such as nausea, vomiting, and abdominal pain.
8. Renal complications: The patient's use of blood products and IV lines may increase the risk of renal complications such as acute kidney injury or chronic kidney disease.
9. Hepatic complications: The patient's use of blood products and IV lines may increase the risk of hepatic complications such as jaundice or liver failure.
10. Psychiatric complications: The patient's critical illness and use of blood products may increase the risk of psychiatric complications such as anxiety, depression, or post-traumatic stress disorder.

   Dark as well as some bright blood were seen in the stomach. A large
   clot that was found adhereing to the fundus during earlier
   endoscopy was now seen to extend from the fundus upto beyond the
   pylorus. After extensive flushing, the clot was dislodged and passed
   below into the antrum and pylorus. Subsequently a subcutaneous
   appearing blood vessel with mild oozing was noted in the fundus, likely
   a Dieulafuoy lesion.[10][1] The vessel was injected with a total of 8ml
   of 1:10,000 epinephrine. Attempts to clip the vessel failed three times
   due to mucosal sloughing. Subsequently the vessel was cauterized with a
   gold probe and hemostasis was achieved.
   Assessment and Plan
   49 y/o F with DM2, HTN,  CAD s/p CABG, admitted/in hospital for MSSA
   bacteremia, charcot foot infected with MSSA, hypotension from sepsis
   with [**Hospital **] transferred from medical [**Hospital1 **] with upper GI bleed likely from
   ASA/Plavix in setting of critical illness and prior hx of ulcers.
   Upper GI Bleed: active bleeding that did not clear with NG lavage.
   Scope x2 yesterday showing clot in stomach the first endoscopy and then
   were able to intervene on second endoscopy with cautery (see GI note).
   Was intubated for second endoscopy and remains intubated.  Not
   adequately responding to a total of 9 PRBCs, 3 plts, and 2 FFP.
   Continues to have melena output.
   -          Maintain [**Location (un) **] and power-PICC (both equivalent to > 18G)
   -          NPO
   -          Maintain active T&S
   -          IV protonix gtt
   -          Transfuse to HCT > 25 given coronary history and baseline
   HCT of 30
   -          Give DDAVP for uremic platelets in the setting of renal
   failure
   -          Q4H HCT
   -          Appreciate GI, surgery and IR recommendation
   Leukocytosis: no clear source other than foot,  known bacteremia which
   has cleared per blood cultures or diarrhea that is c. diff neg. Could
   be stress response to GI bleed
   -          Trend, add on diff
   -          Repeat blood cultures
   -          Follow-up CXR
   -          Follow-up repeat C. diff pending
   -          Repeat Ucx, given foley catheter in place
   -          Monitor clinical exam
   MSSA Bacteremia: repeat blood cultures negative. Temp [**3-7**] to 99.5 on
   standing tylenol.
   -          Continue nafcillin (does not need renal dosing)
   -          Repeat blood cultures
   -          Appreciate ID recommendations
   Left Charcot Foot and Cellulitis:
   -          Continue nafcillin
   -          Follow-up on final tissue cultures
   -          Monitor for improvement
   -          Appreciate podiatric surgery recommendations
   [**Last Name (un) **] d/t ATN: patient without known CKD at baseline. ATN attributed to
   hypotension in setting of MSSA bacteremia. Peak Cr 4.3.
   -          Renally dose all meds
   -          Hold sevelamer while NPO
   -          Monitor UOP, trend Cr
   -          Keep MAPs > 60 to maintain renal perfusion
   -          Appreciate renal consult recommendations
   Hyponatremia: 130,  in setting volume depletion. Has been an issue
   throughout hospitalization and improves with volume and hydration
   -          Hydrate as above
   -          Trend Na with [**Hospital1 **] lytes
   Diarrhea: currently in setting of melena, but prior likely antibiotic
   associated with multiple negative c. diff
   -          When able to tolerate PO initiate yogurt in diet /
   probiotics
   -          Consider loperamide once GI bleed resolves and if there is
   no evidence for infection
   Cervical Disc Disease: C6-C7 disc herniation
   -          Appreciate spine consultation recommendations
   -          Will hold on CT C spine w/o contrast until patient stable
   from a Upper GI bleed perspective
   DM c/b retinopathy, neuropathy:
   -          Lantus to 20 units (half dose) QHS given NPO status
   -          Got 40 units of glargine last night, q2H fingersticks and
   may need D5 drip given NPO
   -          Continue HISS but only treat BG > 200 given currently NPO
   -          Renally dose gabapentin and hold until while patient NPO
   Pain: concern that tylenol could be masking fevers
   -          Stop tylenol for 48 hours to trend temperature curve
   -          Continue dilaudid IV for pain
   HTN:
   -          Continue to hold norvasc, lasix, lopressor, valsartan
   -          Monitor BPs
   CAD s/p CABG [**2197**]:  last intervention > 1 year ago, given acute upper
   GI bleed need to stop ASA and Plavix.
   -          Restart imdur when able
   -          Check EKG
   Diastolic CHF:
   -          Consider using lasix with blood transfusions to prevent
   fluid overload.
   HL: hold atorvastatin and fish oil while NPO
   Anemia, baseline 31: hold iron, MVI
   Vitamin D Deficiency: hold vitamin D

   Dark as well as some bright blood were seen in the stomach. A large
   clot that was found adhereing to the fundus during earlier
   endoscopy was now seen to extend from the fundus upto beyond the
   pylorus. After extensive flushing, the clot was dislodged and passed
   below into the antrum and pylorus. Subsequently a subcutaneous
   appearing blood vessel with mild oozing was noted in the fundus, likely
   a Dieulafuoy lesion.[10][1] The vessel was injected with a total of 8ml
   of 1:10,000 epinephrine. Attempts to clip the vessel failed three times
   due to mucosal sloughing. Subsequently the vessel was cauterized with a
   gold probe and hemostasis was achieved.

   [11][1] Dieulafoy's lesion is a medical condition characterized by a
   large tortuous arteriole in the stomach wall that erodes and bleeds. It
   can cause gastric hemorrhage but is relatively uncommon. It is thought
   to cause less than 5% of all gastrointestinal bleeds in adults. It was
   named after [**Name2 (NI) 4162**] surgeon [**First Name4 (NamePattern1) 98**] [**Name (NI) 11867**] Dieulafoy, who described this
   condition in his paper "Exulceratio simplex: Le
ons [**12-28**]" in 1898. It is
   also called "caliber-persistent artery" or "aneurysm" of gastric
   vessels. However, unlike most other aneurysms these are thought to be
   developmental malformations rather than degenerative changes.

Summary:

The patient is a 49-year-old female with a history of diabetes, hypertension, and coronary artery disease (CAD) who was admitted to the hospital for MSSA bacteremia, Charcot foot infected with MSSA, and hypotension from sepsis. She developed an upper gastrointestinal (GI) bleed likely due to ASA/Plavix in the setting of critical illness and prior history of ulcers. She was intubated for endoscopy and remains intubated. She has received 9 units of packed red blood cells, 3 units of platelets, and 2 units of fresh frozen plasma, but continues to have melena output.

The patient has several medical complications, including:

1. Leukocytosis: No clear source other than foot, known bacteremia which has cleared per blood cultures, or diarrhea which is c. diff negative. Could be stress response to GI bleed.
2. MSSA bacteremia: Repeat blood cultures negative. Temp 99.5 on standing tylenol.
3. Left Charcot foot and cellulitis: Continue nafcillin, follow-up on final tissue cultures, monitor for improvement.
4. Acute tubular necrosis (ATN): Patient without known CKD at baseline. ATN attributed to hypotension in setting of MSSA bacteremia. Peak Cr 4.3.
5. Hyponatremia: 130, in setting volume depletion. Has been an issue throughout hospitalization and improves with volume and hydration.
6. Diarrhea: Currently in setting of melena, but prior likely antibiotic associated with multiple negative c. diff.
7. Cervical disc disease: C6-C7 disc herniation. Hold on CT C spine w/o contrast until patient stable from a Upper GI bleed perspective.
8. DM c/b retinopathy, neuropathy: Lantus to 20 units (half dose) QHS given NPO status.
9. Pain: Concern that tylenol could be masking fevers. Stop tylenol for 48 hours to trend temperature curve.
10. HTN: Continue to hold norvasc, lasix, lopressor, valsartan. Monitor BPs.
11. CAD s/p CABG: Last intervention > 1 year ago, given acute upper GI bleed need to stop ASA and Plavix. Restart imdur when able. Check EKG.
12. Diastolic CHF: Consider using lasix with blood transfusions to prevent fluid overload.

Potential medical complications that can arise:

1. Continued bleeding from the upper GI tract
2. Development of sepsis or septic shock
3. Acute kidney injury or failure
4. Respiratory failure
5. Cardiovascular instability
6. Infection of the wound or surrounding tissue
7. Development of c. diff colitis
8. Worsening of diabetes control
9. Development of hypoglycemia or hyperglycemia
10. Ongoing pain and discomfort

Assessment and Plan:

1. Maintain intubation and power-PICC.
2. NPO status.
3. Maintain active T&S.
4. IV protonix gtt.
5. Transfuse to HCT > 25 given coronary history and baseline HCT of 30.
6. Give DDAVP for uremic platelets in the setting of renal failure.
7. Q4H HCT.
8. Appreciate GI, surgery, and IR recommendation.
9. Trend, add on diff.
10. Repeat blood cultures.
11. Follow-up CXR.
12. Follow-up repeat C. diff pending.
13. Repeat Ucx, given foley catheter in place.
14. Monitor clinical exam.

Note: The patient's condition is complex and requires close monitoring and management by a multidisciplinary team.

   Dark as well as some bright blood were seen in the stomach. A large
   clot that was found adhereing to the fundus during earlier
   endoscopy was now seen to extend from the fundus upto beyond the
   pylorus. After extensive flushing, the clot was dislodged and passed
   below into the antrum and pylorus. Subsequently a subcutaneous
   appearing blood vessel with mild oozing was noted in the fundus, likely
   a Dieulafuoy lesion.[10][1] The vessel was injected with a total of 8ml
   of 1:10,000 epinephrine. Attempts to clip the vessel failed three times
   due to mucosal sloughing. Subsequently the vessel was cauterized with a
   gold probe and hemostasis was achieved.

Summary:

The patient is a 49-year-old female with a history of diabetes, hypertension, coronary artery disease, and chronic kidney disease, who was admitted to the hospital with MSSA bacteremia, charcot foot infected with MSSA, and hypotension from sepsis. She developed an upper GI bleed likely due to ASA/Plavix in the setting of critical illness and prior history of ulcers. She was intubated for the second endoscopy and remains intubated. Despite receiving 9 PRBCs, 3 plts, and 2 FFP, she continues to have melena output.

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Continued bleeding from the upper GI tract, potentially leading to further hypovolemic shock and organ dysfunction.
2. Renal failure, given the patient's pre-existing chronic kidney disease and the need for continued fluid resuscitation.
3. Cardiovascular instability, given the patient's history of coronary artery disease and the potential for further cardiac complications.
4. Sepsis, given the patient's ongoing bacteremia and the risk of further infection.
5. Respiratory failure, given the patient's ongoing need for mechanical ventilation and the risk of further respiratory complications.
6. Gastrointestinal complications, such as perforation or obstruction, given the patient's ongoing GI bleeding and the risk of further GI complications.
7. Hemodynamic instability, given the patient's ongoing need for vasopressors and the risk of further hemodynamic complications.

Assessment and Plan:

1. Continue to monitor the patient's bleeding and hemodynamic status closely.
2. Consider further endoscopy to evaluate the source of bleeding and to assess for any further complications.
3. Continue to provide supportive care, including vasopressors and fluid resuscitation, as needed.
4. Consider further antibiotic therapy to cover potential secondary infections.
5. Monitor the patient's renal function closely and adjust fluid management and medication dosing as needed.
6. Continue to monitor the patient's respiratory status closely and adjust mechanical ventilation settings as needed.
7. Consider further consultation with gastroenterology and interventional radiology to evaluate the patient's bleeding and to assess for any further complications.

Summary:

The patient is a 47-year-old woman with a history of type 2 diabetes, Charcot foot, and coronary artery disease, admitted to the ICU with a chief complaint of gastrointestinal bleed, blood loss anemia, and respiratory failure. She was intubated due to difficult intubation and remains intubated for endoscopy. She has received 9 units of packed red blood cells (pRBCs) and is being managed for acute renal failure (ARF) and acute tubular necrosis (ATN). The patient has ongoing melena due to a Dieulafoy lesion and is scheduled for re-scope this morning. She is also being managed for leukocytosis, hypertension, and hyponatremia.

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Aspiration pneumonia: Given the patient's intubation and inability to protect her airway, there is a risk of aspiration pneumonia.
2. Respiratory failure: The patient's respiratory status is critical, and there is a risk of further deterioration.
3. Sepsis: The patient has a history of bacteremia and is at risk for developing sepsis.
4. Acute kidney injury: The patient's ARF/ATN is a concern, and there is a risk of further kidney damage.
5. Bleeding complications: The patient has ongoing melena and is at risk for further bleeding complications.
6. Skin integrity issues: The patient has a history of Charcot foot and is at risk for skin integrity issues, including cellulitis.
7. Diabetes-related complications: The patient has uncontrolled type 2 diabetes, which puts her at risk for complications such as diabetic ketoacidosis, hyperglycemic hyperosmolar nonketotic syndrome, and peripheral neuropathy.
8. Cardiovascular complications: The patient has a history of coronary artery disease and is at risk for further cardiovascular complications, including myocardial infarction and cardiac arrhythmias.
9. Infection: The patient has a history of bacteremia and is at risk for developing further infections, including ventilator-associated pneumonia and catheter-related bloodstream infections.
10. Nutritional deficiencies: The patient's nutritional status is compromised, and there is a risk of developing deficiencies, including protein-energy malnutrition and vitamin deficiencies.

Summary:

The patient is a 47-year-old woman with a history of type 2 diabetes, Charcot foot, and uncontrolled blood sugar levels. She is currently admitted to the Intensive Care Unit (ICU) due to a gastrointestinal bleed, blood loss anemia, and respiratory failure. The patient has undergone endoscopy and was found to have a Dieulafoy lesion, which is an uncommon cause of gastrointestinal bleeding. She has received 9 units of packed red blood cells and is currently intubated and receiving mechanical ventilation.

The patient's vital signs are stable, with a temperature of 37.5°C, heart rate of 85 beats per minute, and blood pressure of 126/58 mmHg. Her oxygen saturation is 100% on 40% FiO2. She has a respiratory rate of 12 breaths per minute and a Paco2 of 19 mmHg.

The patient's laboratory results show leukocytosis, with a white blood cell count of 21.9 x 10^9/L. Her hemoglobin level is 7.1 g/dL, and her platelet count is 442 x 10^9/L. Her lactate level is 0.9 mmol/L, and her creatinine level is 3.6 mg/dL.

The patient's diagnosis includes gastrointestinal bleeding, blood loss anemia, respiratory failure, and acute kidney injury. She is at risk for aspiration, altered gag reflex, and impaired airway clearance due to her intubation.

Potential medical complications that can arise include:

1. Aspiration pneumonia: The patient's intubation and altered gag reflex make her at risk for aspiration pneumonia.
2. Respiratory failure: The patient's respiratory failure can worsen, leading to further decline in her oxygenation and ventilation.
3. Acute kidney injury: The patient's acute kidney injury can progress to chronic kidney disease or end-stage renal disease if not managed properly.
4. Gastrointestinal bleeding: The patient's gastrointestinal bleeding can worsen, leading to further blood loss and anemia.
5. Infection: The patient's immunosuppressed state and presence of invasive devices make her at risk for infection, including sepsis and bacteremia.
6. Cardiovascular complications: The patient's uncontrolled blood sugar levels and history of coronary artery disease make her at risk for cardiovascular complications, including myocardial infarction and cardiac arrhythmias.
7. Neurological complications: The patient's intubation and altered mental status make her at risk for neurological complications, including seizures and brain damage.

Summary:

The patient is a 49-year-old female with a history of DM2, HTN, CAD, and CABG, admitted to the ICU for MSSA bacteremia, charcot foot infected with MSSA, and upper GI bleed. She was intubated for the second endoscopy and remains intubated due to ongoing melena output and inadequate response to blood transfusions. Her hemoglobin has been increasing, but she continues to require transfusions to maintain a hemoglobin level above 25.

The patient has several medical complications, including:

1. Leukocytosis: The cause is unclear, but it may be related to stress response to the GI bleed.
2. MSSA bacteremia: The patient's blood cultures are negative, and she is being treated with nafcillin.
3. Left Charcot foot and cellulitis: The patient is being treated with nafcillin, and further evaluation is needed.
4. Acute tubular necrosis (ATN): The patient's creatinine level has peaked at 4.3, and she is being treated with supportive care.
5. Hyponatremia: The patient's sodium level is 134, and she is being treated with volume and hydration.
6. Diarrhea: The patient has had diarrhea, which is likely related to antibiotic use.
7. Cervical disc disease: The patient has a C6-C7 disc herniation, which is being monitored.
8. DM: The patient has retinopathy and neuropathy, and her insulin regimen has been adjusted.
9. Pain: The patient is experiencing pain, which is being managed with dilaudid IV.

   bacteremia, charcot foot infected with MSSA, hypotension from sepsis
   with [**Hospital **] transferred from medical [**Hospital1 **] with upper GI bleed likely from
   ASA/Plavix in setting of critical illness and prior hx of ulcers.
   Upper GI Bleed: active bleeding that did not clear with NG lavage.

   able to intervene on second endoscopy with cautery (see GI note).  Was
   intubated for second endoscopy and remains intubated.  Not adequately
   responding to a total of 9 PRBCs, 3 plts, and 2 FFP.  Continues to have
   melena output.
   -          Maintain [**Location (un) **] and power-PICC (both equivalent to > 18G)
   -          NPO
   -          Maintain active T&S
   -          IV protonix gtt
   -          Transfuse to HCT > 25 given coronary history and baseline
   HCT of 30
   -          Give DDAVP for uremic platelets in the setting of renal
   failure
   -          Q4H HCT
   -          Appreciate GI, surgery and IR recommendation
   Leukocytosis: no clear source other than foot,  known bacteremia which
   has cleared per blood cultures or diarrhea that is c. diff neg. Could
   be stress response to GI bleed
   -          Trend, add on diff
   -          Repeat blood cultures
   -          Follow-up CXR
   -          Follow-up repeat C. diff pending
   -          Repeat Ucx, given foley catheter in place
   -          Monitor clinical exam
   MSSA Bacteremia: repeat blood cultures negative. Temp [**3-7**] to 99.5 on
   standing tylenol.
   -          Continue nafcillin (does not need renal dosing)
   -          Repeat blood cultures
   -          Appreciate ID recommendations

   -          Continue nafcillin
   -          Follow-up on final tissue cultures
   -          Monitor for improvement
   -          Appreciate podiatric surgery recommendations
   [**Last Name (un) **] d/t ATN: patient without known CKD at baseline. ATN attributed to
   hypotension in setting of MSSA bacteremia. Peak Cr 4.3.
   -          Renally dose all meds

   -          Trend Na with [**Hospital1 **] lytes
   Diarrhea: currently in setting of melena, but prior likely antibiotic
   associated with multiple negative c. diff

   probiotics
   -          Consider loperamide once GI bleed resolves and if there is
   no evidence for infection

   -          Appreciate spine consultation recommendations
   -          Will hold on CT C spine w/o contrast until patient stable

Summary:

The patient is a 49-year-old female who was admitted to the ICU with MSSA bacteremia, charcot foot infected with MSSA, and hypotension from sepsis. She had a history of DM2, HTN, CAD, and CABG. She was intubated for an upper GI bleed, which was likely caused by ASA/Plavix in the setting of critical illness and prior history of ulcers. The patient has been unresponsive to 9 PRBCs, 3 plts, and 2 FFP, and continues to have melena output.

The patient has multiple medical complications, including:

1. Leukocytosis: No clear source, possibly due to stress response to GI bleed.
2. MSSA Bacteremia: Repeat blood cultures negative, but patient remains on nafcillin.
3. Left Charcot Foot and Cellulitis: Patient remains on nafcillin and awaiting final tissue cultures.
4. Acute Tubular Necrosis (ATN): Patient's creatinine peaked at 4.3, and all medications are being renally dosed.
5. Hyponatremia: Patient has been experiencing volume depletion, and hydration is being continued.
6. Diarrhea: Patient has been experiencing diarrhea, possibly related to antibiotic use or C. diff.
7. Cervical Disc Disease: Patient has a C6-C7 disc herniation, and a spine consultation has been requested.
8. DM: Patient has retinopathy and neuropathy, and is being treated with Lantus and gabapentin.
9. Pain: Patient is experiencing pain, and dilaudid IV is being continued.
10. HTN: Patient's blood pressure is being monitored, and antihypertensive medications are being held.
11. CAD s/p CABG: Patient's last intervention was over a year ago, and ASA and Plavix are being held due to acute upper GI bleed.
12. Diastolic CHF: Patient's heart failure is being monitored, and lasix may be used with blood transfusions to prevent fluid overload.

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Further GI bleeding: Patient's upper GI bleed is ongoing, and there is a risk of further bleeding.
2. Sepsis: Patient's MSSA bacteremia and charcot foot infection put her at risk for sepsis.
3. Renal failure: Patient's ATN and hyponatremia may worsen if not managed properly.
4. Respiratory failure: Patient's respiratory status is being closely monitored, and there is a risk of further deterioration.
5. Cardiac complications: Patient's CAD and CABG put her at risk for cardiac complications, including arrhythmias and infarction.
6. Neurological complications: Patient's DM and neuropathy put her at risk for neurological complications, including stroke and seizures.
7. Infection: Patient's charcot foot and cellulitis put her at risk for further infection.

Summary:

The patient is an intubated individual in the ICU with multiple comorbidities, including diabetes mellitus type II, coronary artery disease, hypertension, and anemia. The patient has a history of gastrointestinal bleeding, bacteremia, and acute renal failure. The patient's hemodynamic monitoring shows a stable condition, with a heart rate of 84 bpm, blood pressure of 127/59 mmHg, and oxygen saturation of 99%. The patient's respiratory support includes mechanical ventilation with CPAP/PSV mode, with a tidal volume of 830 mL and a respiratory rate of 12 breaths per minute.

The patient's laboratory results show anemia, with a hemoglobin level of 9.6 g/dL, and a white blood cell count of 24.9 K/uL. The patient's electrolyte levels are within normal limits, except for a slightly low sodium level of 129 mg/dL. The patient's liver function tests are normal, and the patient's creatinine level is 3.3 mg/dL.

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Aspiration pneumonia: Due to the patient's inability to protect their airway, there is a risk of aspiration, which can lead to pneumonia.
2. Sepsis: The patient's bacteremia and elevated white blood cell count increase the risk of sepsis, which can lead to organ dysfunction and failure.
3. Acute kidney injury: The patient's acute renal failure and elevated creatinine level increase the risk of further kidney damage, which can lead to chronic kidney disease or end-stage renal disease.
4. Gastrointestinal bleeding: The patient's history of gastrointestinal bleeding increases the risk of further bleeding, which can lead to hypovolemic shock and organ failure.
5. Respiratory failure: The patient's respiratory support and mechanical ventilation increase the risk of respiratory failure, which can lead to hypoxemia and hypercapnia.
6. Cardiac complications: The patient's coronary artery disease and hypertension increase the risk of cardiac complications, such as myocardial infarction, heart failure, and arrhythmias.
7. Skin breakdown: The patient's impaired skin integrity and presence of cellulitis increase the risk of further skin breakdown, which can lead to sepsis and organ failure.

Based on the patient's condition and comorbidities, it is essential to closely monitor their vital signs, laboratory results, and respiratory and hemodynamic status to prevent and manage potential complications.

Summary:

The patient is a 47-year-old woman with a history of type II diabetes, Charcot foot, and coronary artery disease, who is currently in the intensive care unit (ICU) with a gastrointestinal (GI) bleed, blood loss anemia, and respiratory failure. She has received 13 units of packed red blood cells (pRBCs) and is being treated with pantoprazole and propofol. Her hemodynamics are stable, but she remains on mechanical ventilation with a fraction of inspired oxygen (FiO2) of 0.4. Her chest X-ray (CXR) is congested, and she has a difficult airway.

Potential medical complications:

1. Aspiration pneumonia: The patient's inability to protect her airway due to mechanical ventilation and altered gag reflex increases the risk of aspiration pneumonia.
2. Sepsis: The patient's bacteremia and leukocytosis may lead to sepsis, which can worsen her respiratory and cardiovascular status.
3. Acute kidney injury (AKI): The patient's acute renal failure (ARF) and decreased serum creatinine (Cr) level may indicate AKI, which can worsen her overall condition.
4. Hypotension: The patient's hypotension and low blood pressure (BP) may indicate inadequate perfusion of vital organs, which can worsen her condition.
5. Hypoxemia: The patient's hypoxemia and low oxygen saturation (SpO2) may indicate inadequate oxygenation, which can worsen her respiratory status.
6. Pneumonia: The patient's congested CXR and respiratory failure increase the risk of developing pneumonia.
7. Cardiovascular instability: The patient's coronary artery disease and hypertension may lead to cardiovascular instability, which can worsen her overall condition.
8. Skin breakdown: The patient's impaired skin integrity and Charcot foot may lead to skin breakdown and pressure ulcers.
9. Infection: The patient's bacteremia and leukocytosis may indicate a systemic infection, which can worsen her overall condition.
10. Gastrointestinal bleeding: The patient's GI bleed and melena may lead to further bleeding and anemia, which can worsen her overall condition.

Based on this information, it is essential to closely monitor the patient's vital signs, laboratory results, and clinical status to prevent or manage these potential complications.

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a 47-year-old woman with a chief complaint of GI bleed and blood loss anemia. She is currently in the MICU and has been receiving treatment for her condition.

The patient's vital signs are as follows:

* Temperature: 37.8°C (100.8°F)
* Heart rate: 83 beats per minute (bpm)
* Blood pressure: 128/57 mmHg
* Respiratory rate: 10 breaths per minute (bpm)
* Oxygen saturation: 99%
* Hemodynamic monitoring: The patient is receiving vasopressors to maintain blood pressure.

The patient's laboratory results show:

* Hemoglobin: 9.6 g/dL
* White blood cell count: 24.9 K/uL
* Platelet count: 53 K/uL
* Creatinine: 3.3 mg/dL
* Blood urea nitrogen (BUN): 129 mg/dL
* Glucose: 154 mg/dL
* Electrolytes: Potassium: 3.9 mEq/L, sodium: 134 mEq/L, chloride: 28.1%, calcium: 7.6 mg/dL, magnesium: 2.1 mg/dL, phosphorus: 6.3 mg/dL

The patient has a history of diabetes mellitus type II, coronary artery disease, and Charcot foot. She has been experiencing gastrointestinal bleeding, which was diagnosed as a Dieulafoy lesion by endoscopy. The patient has received 13 units of packed red blood cells and is planned to undergo rescope today.

The patient's respiratory status is critical, with a requirement for mechanical ventilation and continuous positive airway pressure (CPAP). Her respiratory support is as follows:

* Ventilator mode: CPAP/PSV
* Tidal volume (Vt): 830 mL
* Positive end-expiratory pressure (PEEP): 5 cmH2O
* Fraction of inspired oxygen (FiO2): 40%
* Respiratory system compliance (RSBI): 17

The patient has a history of leukocytosis, which has been trending downward. She is at risk for acute renal failure, and nephrotoxic medications are being held. The patient's skin integrity is compromised, and she has a left Charcot foot with a 6 cm linear incision that probes deep into tissue/ligaments/bone.

The patient's medical complications include:

* Gastrointestinal bleed
* Bacteremia
* Leukocytosis
* Acute renal failure
* Impaired skin integrity
* Cellulitis
* Diabetes mellitus type II
* Coronary artery disease
* Hyponatremia
* Hypertension
* Anemia secondary to blood loss

Based on the patient's condition, the potential medical complications that can arise include:

* Further gastrointestinal bleeding
* Sepsis
* Acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS)
* Acute kidney injury (AKI)
* Cardiovascular instability
* Worsening of skin integrity and cellulitis
* Further complications related to diabetes mellitus type II and coronary artery disease.

The patient's plan of care includes:

* Rescope today to assess the Dieulafoy lesion and determine the cause of the gastrointestinal bleeding
* Continue mechanical ventilation and respiratory support as needed
* Monitor and trend laboratory results, including hemoglobin, white blood cell count, and platelet count
* Hold nephrotoxic medications and continue to monitor renal function
* Continue to manage the patient's skin integrity and wound care
* Monitor and manage the patient's diabetes mellitus type II and coronary artery disease
* Consider diuresis after bleeding issue is resolved prior to extubation.

The patient's electrolyte levels are abnormal, with hypokalemia, hypomagnesemia, and hyperphosphatemia. The patient's liver enzymes are elevated, with an aspartate aminotransferase (AST) level of 134 IU/L and an alanine aminotransferase (ALT) level of 134 IU/L.

The patient's assessment and plan include:

6. Impaired skin integrity
7. Cellulitis in the left charcot foot with a 6 cm linear incision that probes deep into tissue/ligaments/bone at least 1.5 cm
8. Diabetes mellitus (DM), type II, uncontrolled
9. Diarrhea
10. Coronary artery disease (CAD, ischemic heart disease)
11. Hyponatremia (low sodium, hyposmolality)
12. Hypertension, benign
13. Anemia, acute, secondary to blood loss (hemorrhage, bleeding)

The patient's ICU care plan includes:

The patient's disposition is currently the ICU, and the total time spent on the patient's care is 36 minutes. The patient is critically ill and requires close monitoring and management.

Summary:

The patient is a 47-year-old woman with a history of type 2 diabetes, Charcot foot, and coronary artery disease, admitted to the ICU with a GI bleed and blood loss anemia. She is currently receiving mechanical ventilation and has been transfused with 13 units of packed red blood cells (pRBCs). Her hemodynamics are stable, and she is scheduled for an EGD today. She has a difficult airway and will need to be conservative with extubation.

The patient's laboratory results show:

* Hemoglobin: 9.6 g/dL
* Hematocrit: 24.6%
* Platelet count: 53 x 10^3/μL
* White blood cell count: 24.9 x 10^3/μL
* Blood urea nitrogen (BUN): 129 mg/dL
* Creatinine: 3.3 mg/dL
* Glucose: 154 mg/dL

The patient's medical conditions include:

* Gastrointestinal bleed
* Bacteremia (MSSA)
* Leukocytosis
* Acute renal failure (ARF)
* Impaired skin integrity
* Cellulitis in the left Charcot foot
* Uncontrolled type 2 diabetes
* Coronary artery disease
* Hyponatremia
* Hypertension
* Anemia secondary to blood loss

Potential medical complications:

1. Aspiration: The patient has a difficult airway and is at risk for aspiration.
2. Respiratory failure: The patient remains on mechanical ventilation and has a congested chest X-ray.
3. Hemorrhage: The patient has a history of GI bleed and is at risk for further bleeding.
4. Infection: The patient has bacteremia and cellulitis, and is at risk for further infection.
5. Renal failure: The patient has acute renal failure and is at risk for further kidney damage.
6. Skin breakdown: The patient has impaired skin integrity and is at risk for further skin breakdown.
7. Anemia: The patient has anemia secondary to blood loss and is at risk for further anemia.
8. Diabetic complications: The patient has uncontrolled type 2 diabetes and is at risk for diabetic complications such as ketoacidosis or hyperglycemic hyperosmolar nonketotic syndrome.

TEXT:
Chief Complaint:
   24 Hour Events:
   Scoped by GI. Had stable clot, that they did not want to mess around
   with. They discussed the case with surgery. Surgery is following along
   but no immediate plans to take to OR while Hct, and hemodynamics are

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a 49-year-old female with a complex medical history, including diabetes mellitus type 2, hypertension, coronary artery disease (CAD) status post-coronary artery bypass grafting (CABG), and a history of upper gastrointestinal (GI) bleeding. The patient was admitted to the intensive care unit (ICU) for sepsis, MSSA bacteremia, and a charcot foot infected with MSSA.

The patient's current condition is as follows:

* Hemodynamic monitoring: The patient's blood pressure is stable, with a systolic pressure of 137 mmHg and a diastolic pressure of 57 mmHg. Her heart rate is 77 beats per minute, and her respiratory rate is 9 breaths per minute.
* Respiratory status: The patient is intubated and receiving pressure support of 5 and 10. She has a reassuring cuff leak.
* Leukocytosis: The patient has an elevated white blood cell count, but the source of the leukocytosis is unclear.
* MSSA bacteremia: The patient's blood cultures are negative, and she is receiving vancomycin.
* Left charcot foot and cellulitis: The patient has a non-contrast CT scan of the left lower extremity (LLE) showing findings consistent with charcot arthropathy and superimposed osteomyelitis of the mid foot.
* Renal function: The patient's creatinine level is elevated, and she is receiving renal-dose medications.
* Hyponatremia: The patient's sodium level is 136 mmol/L, which has improved with volume and hydration.
* Diarrhea: The patient has a history of diarrhea, which may be related to antibiotic use or infection.
* Cervical disc disease: The patient has a C6-C7 disc herniation, which may require further evaluation and management.

Potential medical complications that may arise include:

* Sepsis: The patient's MSSA bacteremia may lead to sepsis, which could worsen her hemodynamic instability.
* Respiratory failure: The patient's intubation and respiratory support may not be adequate to prevent respiratory failure.
* Renal failure: The patient's elevated creatinine level and decreased urine output may indicate worsening renal function.
* Hyponatremia: The patient's sodium level may continue to fluctuate, potentially leading to hyponatremic seizures or other complications.
* Diarrhea: The patient's diarrhea may worsen, leading to electrolyte imbalances or dehydration.
* Cervical disc disease: The patient's C6-C7 disc herniation may require further evaluation and management, potentially leading to spinal cord compression or other neurological complications.

Given the patient's complex medical history and current condition, it is essential to continue monitoring her closely and adjusting her treatment plan as needed to prevent potential complications and ensure her optimal care.

Based on the progress note, the patient is a 49-year-old female with a complex medical history, including diabetes mellitus type 2, hypertension, coronary artery disease, and a history of upper gastrointestinal bleeding. She was admitted to the ICU with MSSA bacteremia, charcot foot infected with MSSA, and hypotension from sepsis.

The patient's current condition is stable, with a hematocrit (Hct) of 28.6% and hemodynamics stable. She is intubated and receiving mechanical ventilation. Her respiratory status is being closely monitored, and she is being considered for extubation tomorrow.

The patient has a number of potential medical complications that need to be closely monitored:

1. Leukocytosis: The patient's white blood cell count is elevated, and the source of this is unclear. It is possible that it is related to the patient's underlying infection or stress response to the gastrointestinal bleed.
2. MSSA bacteremia: The patient's blood cultures are negative, but she is still receiving vancomycin. The patient's ID recommendations should be closely followed.
3. Left Charcot foot and cellulitis: The patient's foot is infected with MSSA, and she is being followed by podiatry and vascular surgery. A non-contrast CT scan of the left lower extremity showed findings consistent with charcot arthropathy and superimposed osteomyelitis of the mid foot.
4. Acute tubular necrosis (ATN): The patient's creatinine level is elevated, and ATN is attributed to hypotension in the setting of MSSA bacteremia. Renal function should be closely monitored.
5. Hyponatremia: The patient's sodium level is low, and this is being addressed with volume and hydration.
6. Diarrhea: The patient is experiencing diarrhea, which is likely related to her underlying infection or antibiotic use.
7. Cervical disc disease: The patient has a history of cervical disc disease, and this should be closely monitored.
8. Diabetes mellitus: The patient's blood glucose levels should be closely monitored, and her diabetes management plan should be adjusted as necessary.
9. Pain: The patient is experiencing pain, and this should be closely monitored and managed.
10. Upper gastrointestinal bleeding: The patient's bleeding is ongoing, and this should be closely monitored and managed.

In terms of the patient's current medications, she is receiving vancomycin for her MSSA bacteremia, and her ID recommendations should be closely followed. She is also receiving protonix for her upper gastrointestinal bleeding, and her GI bleed should be closely monitored.

In terms of the patient's laboratory results, her white blood cell count is elevated, and her creatinine level is elevated. Her blood glucose levels are being closely monitored, and her diabetes management plan should be adjusted as necessary. Her liver function tests are elevated, and her renal function should be closely monitored.

In terms of the patient's imaging studies, a non-contrast CT scan of the left lower extremity showed findings consistent with charcot arthropathy and superimposed osteomyelitis of the mid foot. A CT scan of the chest showed no acute abnormalities.

In terms of the patient's plan of care, she should continue to receive vancomycin for her MSSA bacteremia, and her ID recommendations should be closely followed. She should continue to receive protonix for her upper gastrointestinal bleeding, and her GI bleed should be closely monitored. She should also continue to receive pain management, and her pain should be closely monitored and managed.

Summary:

The patient is a 68-inch tall, 133.4 kg (overweight/obese) male admitted to the ICU with a diagnosis not specified in the note. The patient has been stable, with no acute distress, and is receiving mechanical ventilation. The patient has a history of allergies to Bactrim, congestive heart failure, and is taking vancomycin and propofol infusions. The patient's laboratory results show stable hemoglobin and platelet counts, but elevated lactate levels and D-dimer. The patient's CT scan of the left lower extremity is pending final readback, but nursing reports that it looked normal. The patient's blood products and fluid balance are being closely monitored.

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Sepsis: Given the patient's history of antibiotic use and elevated lactate levels, sepsis is a potential complication that needs to be closely monitored.
2. Thrombocytopenia: The patient's platelet count is stable, but the note mentions the potential for platelet dysfunction with high-dose nafcillin. This could lead to bleeding complications if not monitored closely.
3. Respiratory failure: The patient is receiving mechanical ventilation, and the note mentions a respiratory rate of 9-10 breaths per minute, which is slightly elevated. This could indicate respiratory failure if not managed properly.
4. Cardiac complications: The patient has a history of congestive heart failure, and the note mentions a blood pressure of 137/57 mmHg, which is slightly elevated. This could indicate cardiac complications if not managed properly.
5. Gastrointestinal complications: The patient's CT scan of the left lower extremity is pending final readback, but nursing reports that it looked normal. This could indicate gastrointestinal complications if not managed properly.
6. DVT: The patient is at risk for DVT given their obesity and immobility. Prophylaxis is being provided, but close monitoring is necessary to prevent this complication.
7. VAP: The patient is at risk for VAP given their mechanical ventilation. Close monitoring and prophylaxis are necessary to prevent this complication.

* Blood pressure: 143/63 mmHg (83-143/71 mmHg)
* Respiratory rate: 11 breaths per minute (8-21 breaths per minute)
* Oxygen saturation: 100%
* SpO2: 100%

The patient has a stable hematocrit (Hct) level of around 27-28% since receiving 2 units of packed red blood cells (PRBCs) approximately 30 hours ago. The patient's GI bleed is currently being managed with serial Hct monitoring, and further intervention is being deferred as long as the Hct level remains stable.

The patient is also experiencing respiratory failure, which is being managed with mechanical ventilation and oxygenation. The patient's respiratory support is being adjusted to aim for extubation tomorrow if the Hct level remains stable.

The patient has a left lower extremity (LLE) infection, which is being managed with antibiotics and close monitoring. The patient's bacteremia is being treated with vancomycin, and the patient's platelet count is being closely monitored.

The patient also has acute kidney injury (AKI) with acute tubular necrosis (ATN), which is being managed with fluid management and close monitoring.

The patient's other medical conditions include diabetes mellitus, type II, uncontrolled, and coronary artery disease.

Potential medical complications that can arise from the patient's current condition include:

1. Re-bleeding from the GI tract, which could lead to further blood loss and anemia.
2. Prolonged respiratory failure, which could lead to further respiratory complications, such as pneumonia or acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS).
3. Sepsis or septic shock, which could be triggered by the patient's bacteremia or LLE infection.
4. Further kidney damage or failure, which could exacerbate the patient's AKI and ATN.
5. Wound complications, such as cellulitis or osteomyelitis, which could arise from the patient's LLE infection.
6. Cardiovascular complications, such as cardiac arrhythmias or acute coronary syndrome, which could arise from the patient's coronary artery disease.

Based on the patient's current condition and potential complications, it is essential to continue close monitoring and management of the patient's GI bleed, respiratory failure, LLE infection, and AKI/ATN.

   Assessment and Plan
   49 y/o F with DM2, HTN,  CAD s/p CABG, admitted/in hospital for MSSA
   bacteremia, charcot foot infected with MSSA, hypotension from sepsis
   with [**Hospital **] transferred from medical [**Hospital1 **] with upper GI bleed likely from
   ASA/Plavix in setting of critical illness and prior hx of ulcers.
   # Upper GI Bleed: active bleeding that did not clear with NG lavage.
   Scope x2 on [**3-7**] showing clot in stomach the first endoscopy and then
   were able to intervene on second endoscopy with cautery (see GI note).
   Was intubated for second endoscopy and remains intubated. 3^rd scope
   [**3-10**] showing clot. Hct has now been stable for the last 24 hours.
   -          Maintain [**Location (un) **] and power-PICC (both equivalent to > 18G)
   -          NPO
   -          Maintain active T&S
   -          IV protonix gtt
   -          Transfuse to HCT > 25 given coronary history and baseline
   HCT of 30 or if drop >3
   -          Space out to Q8H HCT
   # Respiratory Status/Diastolic CHF: Currently doing well intubated on
   pressure support. Difficult intubation with concern for laryngeal
   edema. Has reassuring cuff leak.  Responded well to 20 IV lasix (800cc
   urine).
   -          Extubate today
   -          20 IV lasix this AM, will check PM lytes
   # Leukocytosis: no clear source other than foot, known bacteremia which
   has cleared per blood cultures or diarrhea that is c. diff neg. Could
   be stress response to GI bleed.  No further spread of LLE erythema
   -          Trend WBC
   -          F/U blood cultures
   -          Follow-up CXR
   -          C. Diff has been negative
   -          Monitor clinical exam for spread of erythema over LLE
   # MSSA Bacteremia: repeat blood cultures negative. Temp [**3-7**] to 99.5 on
   standing tylenol.
   -          Vancomycin (stopped nafcillin 3/16 per ID)
   -          F/U repeat blood cultures
   -          Appreciate ID recommendations
   # Left Charcot Foot and Cellulitis: followed by podiatry/vascular
   surgery. Non-Contrast CT of LLE: showed no obvious fluid collection.
   -          Continue vancomycin
   -          Follow-up on final tissue cultures
   -          Monitor for improvement
   -          Appreciate podiatric surgery recommendations
   -          Surgery Recs: [**Hospital1 **] betadine packing, DSD, ace daily
   -          Plan for further debridement once medically stable
   # [**Last Name (un) **] d/t ATN: patient without known CKD at baseline. ATN attributed to
   hypotension in setting of MSSA bacteremia. Peak Cr 4.3.
   -          Renally dose all meds
   -          Hold sevelamer while NPO
   -          Monitor UOP, trend Cr
   -          Keep MAPs > 60 to maintain renal perfusion
   -          Appreciate renal consult recommendations
   # HTN: reasonably well controlled at present
   -          Diurese today as above
   -          Continue to hold norvasc, lopressor, valsartan in setting of
   GIB
   -          Monitor BPs
   Hyponatremia: Resolved. Initially 130 in setting volume depletion. Has
   been an issue throughout hospitalization and improves with volume and
   hydration.  Na is 137 this morning.
   Diarrhea: currently in setting of melena, but prior likely antibiotic
   associated with multiple negative c. diff
   -          When able to tolerate PO initiate yogurt in diet /
   probiotics
   -          Consider loperamide once GI bleed resolves and if there is
   no evidence for infection
   Cervical Disc Disease: C6-C7 disc herniation
   -          Will hold on CT C spine w/o contrast until patient stable
   from a Upper GI bleed perspective
   DM c/b retinopathy, neuropathy:
   -          Lantus to 10 units (half dose) QHS given NPO status
   -          Continue HISS but only treat BG > 200 given currently NPO
   -          Renally dose gabapentin and hold until while patient NPO
   Pain: concern that tylenol could be masking fevers
   -          Continue dilaudid IV for pain
   CAD s/p CABG [**2197**]:  last intervention > 1 year ago, given acute upper
   GI bleed need to stop ASA and Plavix.
   -          Restart imdur when able
   -          Check EKG
   HL: hold atorvastatin and fish oil while NPO
   Vitamin D Deficiency: hold vitamin D
   Nutrition: NPO

Based on the provided progress note, I summarize the patient's condition as follows:

The patient is a 49-year-old female with a history of diabetes mellitus type 2, hypertension, coronary artery disease, and chronic kidney disease. She was admitted to the hospital for MSSA bacteremia, charcot foot infection, and upper gastrointestinal bleed. She underwent endoscopy and was intubated due to the severity of the bleed. The patient has been receiving vancomycin for MSSA bacteremia and has shown improvement in her condition.

The patient's vital signs are stable, with a temperature of 37.6°C, heart rate of 84 beats per minute, blood pressure of 138/52 mmHg, and respiratory rate of 11 breaths per minute. Her oxygen saturation is 98% on 40% fraction of inspired oxygen.

The patient's laboratory results show a white blood cell count of 14.6 x 10^9/L, hemoglobin of 9.7 g/dL, and platelet count of 108 x 10^9/L. Her blood urea nitrogen and creatinine levels are elevated, indicating kidney dysfunction. Her liver function tests are normal, and her electrolyte levels are within normal limits.

The patient has several potential medical complications, including:

1. Respiratory failure: The patient is intubated and receiving pressure support, but she may require extubation soon. There is a risk of laryngeal edema and respiratory failure if the patient is not carefully monitored.
2. Sepsis: The patient has MSSA bacteremia, which can lead to sepsis and organ dysfunction if not properly treated.
3. Renal failure: The patient's kidney function is compromised, and there is a risk of acute kidney injury or chronic kidney disease if not managed properly.
4. Diabetic ketoacidosis: The patient has diabetes mellitus type 2, and there is a risk of diabetic ketoacidosis if her blood glucose levels are not properly managed.
5. Gastrointestinal bleeding: The patient has ongoing upper gastrointestinal bleeding, which can lead to hypovolemic shock and multi-organ failure if not properly managed.
6. Leukocytosis: The patient has an elevated white blood cell count, which may indicate infection or inflammation.
7. Charcot foot: The patient has charcot foot, which can lead to foot ulcers and amputation if not properly managed.
8. Hypotension: The patient has a history of hypertension, but her blood pressure is currently low, which may indicate hypotension or shock.

In summary, the patient has a complex medical condition with multiple potential complications. She requires close monitoring and management to prevent and treat these complications.

   Assessment and Plan
   49 y/o F with DM2, HTN,  CAD s/p CABG, admitted/in hospital for MSSA
   bacteremia, charcot foot infected with MSSA, hypotension from sepsis
   with [**Hospital **] transferred from medical [**Hospital1 **] with upper GI bleed likely from
   ASA/Plavix in setting of critical illness and prior hx of ulcers.
   # Upper GI Bleed: active bleeding that did not clear with NG lavage.
   Scope x2 Sat showing clot in stomach the first endoscopy and then were
   able to intervene on second endoscopy with cautery (see GI note).  Was
   intubated for second endoscopy and remains intubated. 3^rd scope
   Tuesday showing clot. Hct has now been stable for the last 24 hours.
   -          Maintain [**Location (un) **] and power-PICC (both equivalent to > 18G)
   -          NPO
   -          Maintain active T&S
   -          IV protonix gtt
   -          Transfuse to HCT > 25 given coronary history and baseline
   HCT of 30 or if drop >3
   -          Continue Q4H HCT
   # Respiratory Status/Diastolic CHF: Currently doing well intubated on
   pressure support. Difficult intubation with concern for laryngeal
   edema. Has reassuring cuff leak.
   -          Keep even today
 if stable bleed, consider diuresis
   -          plan to extubate tomorrow
   -          continue propofol gtt
   # Leukocytosis: no clear source other than foot, known bacteremia which
   has cleared per blood cultures or diarrhea that is c. diff neg. Could
   be stress response to GI bleed.
   -          Trend WBC
   -          F/U blood cultures
   -          Follow-up CXR
   -          C. Diff has been negative
   -          Monitor clinical exam for spread of erythema over LLE
   # MSSA Bacteremia: repeat blood cultures negative. Temp [**3-7**] to 99.5 on
   standing tylenol.
   -          Vancomycin (stopped nafcillin 3/16 per ID)
   -          Repeat blood cultures
   -          Appreciate ID recommendations
   # Left Charcot Foot and Cellulitis: followed by podiatry/vascular
   surgery. Non-Contrast CT of LLE:
   -          Continue vancomycin
   -          Follow-up on final tissue cultures
   -          Monitor for improvement
   -          Appreciate podiatric surgery recommendations
   -          Vascular recommends noncontrast CT of LLE
   -          Surgery Recs: [**Hospital1 **] betadine packing, DSD, ace daily
   -          Plan for further debridement once medically stable
   # [**Last Name (un) **] d/t ATN: patient without known CKD at baseline. ATN attributed to
   hypotension in setting of MSSA bacteremia. Peak Cr 4.3.
   -          Renally dose all meds
   -          Hold sevelamer while NPO
   -          Monitor UOP, trend Cr
   -          Keep MAPs > 60 to maintain renal perfusion
   -          Appreciate renal consult recommendations
   # HTN: reasonably well controlled at present
   -          Diurese today as above
   -          Continue to hold norvasc, lopressor, valsartan in setting of
   GIB
   -          Monitor BPs
   Hyponatremia: Resolved. Initially 130 in setting volume depletion. Has
   been an issue throughout hospitalization and improves with volume and
   hydration.  Na is 136 this morning.
   Diarrhea: currently in setting of melena, but prior likely antibiotic
   associated with multiple negative c. diff
   -          When able to tolerate PO initiate yogurt in diet /
   probiotics
   -          Consider loperamide once GI bleed resolves and if there is
   no evidence for infection
   Cervical Disc Disease: C6-C7 disc herniation
   -          Appreciate spine consultation recommendations
   -          Will hold on CT C spine w/o contrast until patient stable
   from a Upper GI bleed perspective
   DM c/b retinopathy, neuropathy:
   -          Lantus to 20 units (half dose) QHS given NPO status
   -          Continue HISS but only treat BG > 200 given currently NPO
   -          Renally dose gabapentin and hold until while patient NPO
   Pain: concern that tylenol could be masking fevers
   -          Stop tylenol for 48 hours to trend temperature curve
   -          Continue dilaudid IV for pain
   CAD s/p CABG [**2197**]:  last intervention > 1 year ago, given acute upper
   GI bleed need to stop ASA and Plavix.
   -          Restart imdur when able
   -          Check EKG
   HL: hold atorvastatin and fish oil while NPO
   Vitamin D Deficiency: hold vitamin D
   Sugar Control:  Will follow sugars closely, consider backing down on
   her glucose control today.

Summary:

The patient is a 49-year-old female with a history of DM2, HTN, CAD, and s/p CABG, admitted to the ICU for MSSA bacteremia, charcot foot infected with MSSA, and upper GI bleed. The patient was intubated for an endoscopy and remains intubated. The patient has been stable for the last 24 hours, with no further bleeding. The patient's Hct has been stable, and the patient is currently receiving vancomycin for MSSA bacteremia.

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Respiratory Complications: The patient is intubated and receiving pressure support. There is a concern for laryngeal edema, and the patient may need to be extubated tomorrow.
2. Leukocytosis: The patient has leukocytosis, which may be due to the foot infection, bacteremia, or stress response to the GI bleed. The patient's WBC will need to be trended, and blood cultures will be repeated.
3. MSSA Bacteremia: The patient has MSSA bacteremia, which has cleared per blood cultures. The patient will continue to receive vancomycin.
4. Left Charcot Foot and Cellulitis: The patient has left charcot foot and cellulitis, which will require further debridement once the patient is medically stable.
5. ATN: The patient has ATN attributed to hypotension in setting of MSSA bacteremia. The patient's Cr will need to be trended, and the patient will need to be monitored for UOP.
6. HTN: The patient's HTN is reasonably well-controlled, but the patient will need to be monitored for BPs.
7. Hyponatremia: The patient's hyponatremia has resolved, but the patient will need to be monitored for Na levels.
8. Diarrhea: The patient has diarrhea, which may be due to the GI bleed or antibiotics. The patient will need to be monitored for stool cultures.
9. Cervical Disc Disease: The patient has cervical disc disease, which will require further evaluation once the patient is stable from an upper GI bleed perspective.
10. DM: The patient has DM, which will require close monitoring of sugar control.
11. Pain: The patient is experiencing pain, which will need to be managed with analgesics.
12. CAD: The patient has CAD, which will require further evaluation once the patient is stable.

Overall, the patient is stable, but there are several potential medical complications that need to be monitored and managed.

Summary:

The patient is a 68-inch tall, 133.4 kg male who was admitted to the ICU with congestive heart failure. Over the past 24 hours, the patient has been diuresing with 800cc of fluid, and has received 20mg of Lasix. The patient's blood sugar levels have been low, so the regular insulin dose has been reduced from 40 to 16 units. The patient's phosphate levels are rising.

The patient's vital signs are stable, with a temperature of 37.6°C, heart rate of 84bpm, and blood pressure of 138/52mmHg. The patient is receiving mechanical ventilation with a CPAP/PSV mode, and is being oxygenated with 40% FiO2.

The patient's lab results show a white blood cell count of 14.6, hemoglobin of 27.5, and platelet count of 345. The patient's creatinine is 2.3, glucose is 65, and phosphate is 6.9mg/dL.

The patient is at risk for developing medical complications, including:

1. Hyperkalemia: The patient's phosphate levels are rising, which can lead to hyperkalemia.
2. Hypoglycemia: The patient's blood sugar levels are low, which can lead to hypoglycemia.
3. Respiratory failure: The patient is receiving mechanical ventilation, and is at risk for developing respiratory failure.
4. Sepsis: The patient is at risk for developing sepsis, given the presence of a PICC line and the patient's underlying medical conditions.
5. Deep vein thrombosis: The patient is at risk for developing deep vein thrombosis, given the presence of a PICC line and the patient's immobility.

The patient's care plan should include:

1. Monitoring of the patient's phosphate levels and adjusting the patient's treatment accordingly.
2. Monitoring of the patient's blood sugar levels and adjusting the patient's treatment accordingly.
3. Adjusting the patient's mechanical ventilation settings as necessary.
4. Monitoring the patient for signs of sepsis and adjusting the patient's treatment accordingly.
5. Considering the use of prophylactic anticoagulation therapy to prevent deep vein thrombosis.
